metadata.title: How do proteins ‘response’ to common carbon nanomaterials?

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Advances in Colloid and Interface Science
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /c i s
Historical Perspective
How do proteins ‘response’ to common carbon nanomaterials?
Xianfeng Wang a,1, Yi Zhu b,1, Ming Chen a,⁎, Ming Yan a,⁎, Guangming Zeng a, Danlian Huang a a College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Hunan University and Key Laboratory of Environmental Biology and Pollution Control (Hunan University), Ministry of Education, Changsha 410082, PR China b School of Environmental Science & Engineering, Hubei Polytechnic University, Huangshi 435003, PR China
⁎ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: mchensn@hnu.edu.cn (M. Chen), ym 1 These authors contribute equally to this article.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cis.2019.06.002 0001-8686/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: 30 May 2019 Available online 05 June 2019
Carbon nanomaterials are widely produced and applied in biological and environmental fields because of their outstanding physical and chemical properties, which pose a threat to the safety of living organisms and the ecological environment. Therefore, understanding how carbon nanomaterials and their derivatives work on organisms is becoming important. In recent years, more and more researchers have explored the damage of carbon nanomaterials to organisms at the molecular level. This review pays special emphasis on how proteins response to themain carbonnanomaterials (fullerene, carbon nanotubes, graphene and their derivatives). In addition, how to use the interaction between carbon nanomaterials and proteins to do some beneficial things for human and the development of safe nanomaterials is simply discussed. Finally, some suggestions have been made to lay a theoretical foundation for future research.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. Keywords: Protein-nanomaterial interaction Enzyme Fullerenes Carbon nanotubes Graphene Derivative of carbon nanomaterials

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Carbon nanomaterials have at least one dimension less than 100 nm [1]. The dispersed phase of carbon nanomaterials may be composed of carbon atoms or heterogeneous atoms (non-carbon atoms), and may even be nanopores. Three different dimensions, zero-dimensional (fullerene), one-dimensional (carbon nanotubes, CNTs) and twodimensional (graphene), are the fundamental forms of carbon nanomaterials [2]. Fullerene, as a new type of carbon nanomaterial, was discovered in 1985 [3] with 20 hexagons and 12 pentagons, consisted of 32 faces [4]. Fullerene exhibited superior performance in
8188@hnu.edu.cn (M. Yan).
superconductivity, magnetism, optics, catalytic and biocompatibility due to their high degree of symmetry [5]. Almost insoluble in water and sparingly soluble in polar solvent may be one of the disadvantages of fullerenes [6]. CNTs, also called buckytubes, are seamless, hollow nanotubes that are composed by single or multi-layer graphite sheets curled at a certain angle around the center [7]. CNTs can be classified into single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) [2]. CNTs can be synthesized by arc discharge method, chemical vapor deposition, laser method, template method, etc [8,9]. CNTs are widely used in biological fields such as drug carriers, bio-imaging, and biosensors [10,11]. Graphene is a single layer film composed of sp2-hybridized carbon atoms with extremely high crystal and electron quality [12]. In addition, graphene has a theoretical surface area of up to 2630 m2/g that is higher than many materials [13].
With the development and application of carbon nanomaterials, the possibility of living organism exposure to carbon nanomaterials will increase (Fig. 1).Moreover, carbon nanomaterials can enter the organism, andwill not change or degrade during the transfer process [14]. Proteins are the most abundant organic compounds in cells which are the basic unit of structure and function of organisms [15]. Therefore, studying the relationship between proteins and carbon nanomaterials is the key to understanding the potential toxicity of carbon nanomaterials to organisms. This review summarizes the recent research results of interactions between carbon nanomaterials and proteins, then briefly introduces the mechanism of their interactions. And how to use their relationship to do some beneficial things for human and the development of safe carbon nanomaterials are simply described, which will contribute to future research. Since most enzymes are proteins, this article also covers the introduction of carbon nanomaterials and enzyme relationships.

sections.heading: 2. Response of proteins to fullerenes
sections.text:
Functionalization of fullerenes or attachment of fullerenes to biomolecules to obtain new compounds will improve the solubility of fullerenes and have the dual properties of fullerenes and biomolecules. Therefore, many scientists have studied and reported fullerene derivatives with –OH, –COOH, –NH2, amino acids, enzymes, proteins, etc. Fullerenes and their derivatives have different effects on the structure or activity of the proteins (Table 1), depending on the type of proteins (enzymes), the structure of the carbon nanomaterials, and the chemical groups attached to the nanomaterials [16].
Fullerenes can inhibit proteases by binding to protease active sites, and not all inhibition of protein activity is detrimental. HIV-1 protease is one of the key enzymes in the replication process of the HIV-1 genome, and the inhibition of enzyme activity is one way to slow down gene expression. There are some reports about how to use the combined nanomaterials and enzymes to inhibit the activity of HIV-1 protease. As early as 1993, water soluble fullerene derivatives were first built by Friedman et al. [17] via the program DOCK3. It has been found that the fullerene derivative interacted with the active site of the HIV-1 protease and fullerene derivatives had an inhibitory effect on HIV-1 protease. In addition, Zhu et al. [18] have conducted amore in-depth study on the interaction between fullerene derivatives and HIV-1 protease. The result showed that hydrophobic surface area by maximizing the
desolvation of the compound could improve the activity of inhibitor compounds, which are the same as Friedman et al. Moreover, the paper provides amolecularmechanism for the flexible flaps to promote the combining of an inhibitor. Nakamura et al. synthesized two different water-soluble fullerene derivatives [19]. And they found that the detergent type of fullerene derivative could inhibit the enzyme activity through reversible and competitive ways. After that, Barzegar [20] constructed new carbon nanostructures of fullerenewith one and two polar acetoxyhydroxyl groups (C60-A and C60-B, respectively) and analyzed the interactions and the binding affinity of HIV-1 protease active site and fullerene. They found that the higher affinity of C60-A and C60-B compared to C60 when they interacted with HIV-1 protease. Furthermore, C60-B interacted with the active site more efficiently than C60-A. Different functional groups of fullerenes may have unequal water solubility and inhibitory effects on HIV protease. The insoluble nature of fullerenes limits their application as an inhibitor. Finding new functional groups to increase thewater solubility of fullerenes is essential for effectively inhibitingHIV-1 protease and improving the van derWaals forces of C60 and protease.
In addition to inhibiting HIV-1 protease, fullerenes and their derivatives could act as inhibitors of the zinc enzymes carbonic anhydrases [21]. Kankanala et al. [22] found that fullerene derivatives housing – OH, –NH2, and amino acid modified groups inhibited key antioxidant enzymes because fullerene derivatives binds to the active site residues of the amino acids in these enzymes via van der Waals interactions. In 2016, protein tyrosine phosphatases with comparable shape and size were found to be more easily combined with fullerene inhibitors [23]. One year later, Esimbekova et al. [24] demonstrated that fullerene inhibited oxidoreductase and luciferase, while the immobilized enzyme system oxidoreductase and luciferase were more sensitive to fullerene. Yu et al. [25] also confirmed that the amino-modified fullerene derivative had a significant inhibitory effect on protein tyrosine phosphatase and could be used as an effective inhibitor. The inhibition of proteins and enzymes by fullerenes may has a negative effect on the organism. Nevertheless, there are few studies on how to reduce the inhibition of the interaction between fullerenes and proteins. Therefore, it is a good way to study at the molecular level how to maintain the characteristics of fullerenes and proteins after the interaction of fullerenes with proteins.
Fullerene also can promote the stability of proteins in addition to inhibiting protein activity, which can be applied to the medical field.
nomaterials on proteins.
Table 1 The mechanism of interaction between fullerene and proteins.
Carbon nanomaterials Proteins Mechanism for their interactions Ref
Fullerene and fullerene derivatives
HIV-1 protease HIV-1 protease were inhibited by fullerene with phenethylamino- succinate [17] Fullerene-based HIV protease inhibitor influenced the enzyme activity through reversible and competitive ways [18,19] The higher affinity of fullerene with polar acetoxyhydroxyl groups compared to C60 when they interacted with HIV-1 protease. [20] Zinc enzymes Fullerenes and their derivatives could act as inhibitors of the zinc enzymes carbonic anhydrases [21] Antioxidant enzymes Fullerene binds to the active site residues of these enzymes via van der Waals interactions [22] Tyrosine phosphatases Protein tyrosine phosphatases with comparable shape and size were found to be more easily combined with fullerene inhibitors [23] The amino-modified fullerene derivative had a significant inhibitory effect on protein tyrosine phosphatase [25] Lysozyme Lysozyme was used as a model protein to study the reaction mechanism of protein and fullerene [26] Fullerene binding polar groups can reduce the binding between lysozyme and fullerene derivatives [29] Soybean peroxidase Fullerene with the highly curved surface can enhance the stability of the enzyme strongly [30]
Prabha et al. [26] synthesized and isolated lysozyme-fullerene complex for the first time in 2005. And lysozyme was used as a model protein to study the reactionmechanism of protein and fullerene, whichwould be beneficial to the biomedical application of fullerenes. Through molecular docking technology it was found that fullerene binding to polar groups could reduce the binding between proteins and fullerene derivatives [29]. Asuri et al. [30] discovered that fullerene with the highly curved surface could enhance the stability of the enzyme (soybean peroxidase) strongly in denaturing environments to greater extent than flat supports. It can be seen that the enzyme stability can be enhanced by conjugated fullerene and enzymes, which have a major impact on many areas such as medical diagnostics, sensor and nanocomposite design and drug delivery. Fullerenes also can protect proteins from damage caused by reactive oxygen species besides promote proteins stability [31]. Fullerene phenylalanine derivatives were synthesized by Yang et al. [27], and subsequently were found to have antioxidant function [28]. Most studies have focused on highly water-soluble chemically modified fullerenes such as the fullerene phenylalanine derivatives described above. But it isworth noting that the unmodified fullerene is less biotoxic to proteins than its derivatives under certain conditions [32]. Thus understanding the response of proteins to fullerenes is critical to the widespread use of fullerenes.

sections.heading: 3. Response of proteins to CNTs
sections.text:
Some researchers have reported on the mechanism of interaction between CNTs and proteins (Table 2). Galeska et al. [33] showed that most of the proteins in the aqueous solution spontaneously adsorbed
onto the carbon nanotubes, and the complex formed by proteins and CNTs caused a change in the conductivity of the CNTs. Some studies have observed the strong adsorption of fibrinogen on the surface of SWCNTs by scanning electron microscopy and near edge X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy [34]. It is believed that the change in the conductivity of CNTs is caused by the electron donating or electron withdrawing groups of the proteins. Sengupta et al. [35] also concluded that charge transfer could strongly influence the interaction between proteins and carbon nanomaterials and enhanced conformational entropy by inducing protein unfolding. In addition to the influence of charge transfer, the interaction of carbon nanomaterials and proteins are also related to van der Waals force and Coulomb force, which was confirmed in the experiments of β-amyloid peptides fibrillation and CNTs interaction [36]. A year later, Barzegar et al. [37] found that the aromatic content of surface-active peptides in proteins also plays an significant role in the adsorption of SWCNTs through molecular dynamics simulations.
Many studies have confirmed the organisms toxicity of carbon nanomaterials [38], and the potential toxicity would be affected by CNTs with different degrees of densities and agglomeration. In 2016, Zhao et al. [39] used molecular dynamic simulation to study the inhibition of α-chymotrypsin (α-ChT) by carboxyl-functionalized SWCNTs with different densities. After comparison, the author concludes that the functional density of SWCNTs has a significant influence on the orientation of a-ChT and the active site conformation. Then Geldert et al. [40] concluded that the binding mechanism of carbon nanomaterials and plasma proteins might intensely rely on the oxygen density of the nanomaterials, especially the number of C\\O and C_O bonds. And to
some extent, the dimension, surface curvature and surface area of carbon nanomaterials would also affect their interaction. Elsayed et al. [41] explain that in the presence of SWCNTs with experiments, and the metabolism of drugs in the organism can be disturbed. However, polyethylene glycol covalently functionalized SWCNTs and SWCNT pre-coated bovine serum albumin can alleviate the inhibition of P450 enzyme activity [41]. Zhang et al. [42] added MWCNTs, and carboxylic functionalized MWCNTs to 10 mg/L atrazine respectively, and compared the effects of CNTs on bacterial growth. The results showed that CNTs could promote or inhibit biodegradation by balancing the toxic effects onmicrobial activity with changes in bioavailability resulting from adsorption and desorption. Forestet et al. found that lactate dehydrogenase spontaneously adsorbs CNTs when CNTs interact with lactate dehydrogenase, and the artifacts occurred in specific conditions, which may be due to the inherent absorption of CNTs [43].. The microbial enzyme-catalyzed courses of organic contaminants would be significantly affected by SWCNT release [44]. Subsequently, Chen et al. [45] found that in the presence of SWCNTs, maleylpyruvate isomerase and lignin peroxidase were induced with significant conformational transformation, and the protein tightnesswas changed and the protein cavity was adjusted. In addition, they also studied the interaction of carbon nanotubes with manganese peroxidase during the biodegradation of endocrine disruptors and triclosan. And the results of this study show that nanomaterials alter the amount and behavior of water molecules adjacent to manganese peroxidase and its substrates [46]. Moreover, Sahihi et al. [47] found that SWCNTs could change the microenvironment and conformation of human serum albumin. In 2018, enzyme activity, adsorption, thermostability and conformational changes were measured after the interaction of carboxylic functionalized MWCNTs and porcine trypsin. And the result showed that the thermal stability and activity of porcine trypsin were reduced in the presence of carboxylic functionalized MWCNTs, while carboxylic functionalized MWCNTs had tiny effect on the conformational change of the porcine trypsin [48]. Homaei et al. [49] studied the activity and stability of papain adsorbed by MWCNTs. While, they found that MWCNTs did not significantly block the mass transfer, which had an active influence on the thermal stability of papain, and even could protect the active conformation of the enzyme. According to the above discussion, it is known that the influence of CNTs on protein activity and stability has not been sufficiently explored, and there are many contradictions in the literature. Most of the research uses several common proteins such as serum proteins, papain,while research on other proteins is still rare，which is also worthy of attention in the future research.
Some scientists have also studied the cytotoxicity of CNTs at different degrees of agglomeration. Wick et al. [50] found that the dispersed CNTs were the least toxic, and the nanotoxicity of agglomeration was much greater than that of asbestos fibers. Zhao et al. [51] prepared functionalized MWCNTs with diverse diameters and used some equipment to observe the conformation of protein, backbone changes, and the secondary structural stability. This experiment proved that the diameter and surface of the CNTs were playing an important role in influencing adsorption protein stability. Moreover, the adsorption of bovine serum albumin by CNTs reduces the stability of secondary and tertiary structures, and the smaller the diameter, the worse the stability. Yu et al. [52] investigated the difference between the binding of individual SWCNTs and polymerized SWCNTs to dopamine-related proteins through all-atom molecular dynamic simulation. The results suggested that dopamine-related protein can adsorb onto these SWCNTs and aggregated SWCNTs have a more significant effect on protein activity. Thus, the polymerization of carbon nanomaterials rather than diameter acts an important role in adjusting enzyme activity.
Due to the cytotoxicity of carbon nanomaterials, enzymatic degradation of CNTs has also been studied. Four kinds of oxidized MWCNTs were synthesized, and xanthine oxidase (XO) and horseradish peroxidase (HRP) were used to examine the biodegradability of MWCNTs by Sureshbabu et al. [53]. This experiment indicated that the MWCNTs
with special functionalmolecules could result in accelerating nanotubes degradation compared to commonly oxidized CNTs. Zhang et al. [54] compared the enzymatic transformation of SWCNTs and carboxylated SWCNTs by using three enzymes to explore the enzyme degradation mechanism of SWCNTs. The results suggested that manganese peroxidase degraded SWCNTs but not carboxylated SWCNTs, maybe because at the enzyme binding site, Mn2+ bound to surface carboxyl groups. Thus, functionalization of oxygenated surfaces maybe not necessarily promote the ability to biodegrade CNTs. After that, Chen et al. [55] provided a molecular basis for the degradation of CNTs by comparing the interaction of manganese peroxidase and lignin peroxidase with CNTs. In addition, they also found that the original CNTs are difficult to be degraded by enzymes, such as horseradish peroxidase and lactoperoxidase, and CNT biodegradation usually requires functionalization [56]. The biodegradationmethods of CNTs aremoving from theory to rational restoration practices to remove these materials from the environment, but there are still manyproblems. Biodegradable CNTs can be considered from two aspects of reducing the toxicity of CNTs or completely removing CNTs in the environment. Further efforts should primarily aim to expand the enzymes and study the most suitable conditions for carbon nanomaterial degradation.

sections.heading: 4. Response of proteins to graphene
sections.text:
Since Novoselov et al. [57] first reported a naturally occurring graphene and demonstrated its unique physicochemical properties, more and more people have studied this material. Graphene oxide is one of the important derivatives of graphene. Graphene is hydrophobic, while graphene oxide is easily soluble in water and many solvents [58]. Graphene oxide has lower conductivity than graphene due to the introduction of oxygen-containing functional group. The preparation of graphene oxide mainly includes Brodie method [59], Staudenmaier method [60] and electrochemical oxidation method. Since graphene and its derivatives have a wide range of applications, in order to evaluate the biological effects of graphene, many scholars have reported the interaction between graphene and its derivatives and proteins (Table 3).
The toxicity of graphene depends on the chemical structure, surface properties, size, dosage, and exposure time of graphene [61,62]. Luan et al. [63] used all-atommolecular dynamics simulations to analyze potential toxicity of graphene via the hydrophobic protein-protein interactions and concluded that a graphene nanosheet can interrupt the hydrophobic protein-protein interaction and even result in the mortality of a cell. De et al. [64] demonstrated that graphene oxide exhibited the highest inhibition dose response for α-ChT inhibition. The relationship between the microbial community of wastewater and graphene oxide was investigated by Ahmed et al. [65], and they found that the toxicity of graphene oxide to microorganisms was dose-dependent. The size, surface charge, number of layers, environmental conditions, and physicochemical characteristics of graphene can affect the interaction between graphene and protein. However, the biotoxicity research of graphene is still controversial inmolecular simulations and actual experiments, which requires us to explore further.
Graphene oxide is one of the important derivatives of graphene, and its interaction with proteins also should be focused. Sopotnik et al. [66] studied the reaction of three carbon nanomaterials (carbon black,multiwalled carbon nanotubes, graphene oxide) with serum albumin, and measured the binding strength of serum albumin to these three nanomaterials. It was found that graphene oxide had a higher adsorption capacity for serum albumin, but its binding specificity was low. Zhang et al. [67] found that both graphene and graphene oxide obviously reduced enzyme stability by changing enzyme conformation through the experiment of the interaction between horseradish peroxidase and three graphene-based nanomaterials. In order to explore the influence of graphene oxide on the conformational changes of amyloid beta peptide, Baweja et al. [68] used molecular dynamic simulations to
Table 3 The mechanism of interaction between graphene and proteins.
Nanomaterials Proteins Mechanism for their interactions Ref
Graphene Blood proteins Graphene could interrupt the hydrophobic protein-protein interaction [63] Horseradish peroxidase Both graphene obviously reduced enzyme stability by changing enzyme conformation [67] Graphene oxide α-ChT Graphene oxide exhibited high inhibition response for α-ChT [64] Serum albumin Graphene oxide had a high adsorption capacity for serum albumin, but its binding specificity was low [66]
Graphene oxide could improve the structure and activity of enzymes by preadsorbing highly cationized bovine serum albumin [71] Hemoglobin Graphene oxide could make hemoglobin more susceptible to thermal denaturation and prevent non-enzymatic glycosylation of
hemoglobin [69]
Glucose oxidase Graphene oxide has no competitive inhibition on glucose oxidase, but has competitive inhibition on L-lactate dehydrogenase [70]
carry out this investigation. The result proved that graphene oxide and reduced graphene oxide could restrain the toxic changes of amyloid beta peptide, and reduced graphene oxidewasmore efficient for the inhibition. In 2016, Wang et al. [69] studied the affinity, conformational structure, thermal stability and non-enzymatic glycosylation of graphene oxide-hemoglobin binding by fluorescence spectroscopy and circular dichroism spectroscopy. They concluded that graphene oxide could make hemoglobin more susceptible to thermal denaturation and also prevent non-enzymatic glycosylation of hemoglobin. Furthermore, grapheneoxide interfered strongly the secondary structure of hemoglobin by forming hemoglobin-graphene oxide aggregates. Recently, Maiti et al. [70] investigated the interaction of graphene oxide with two enzymes: glucose oxidase and L-lactate dehydrogenase. And the experiment showed that graphene oxide had no competitive inhibition on glucose oxidase, while it was the opposite of L-lactate dehydrogenase.
In order to better use graphene and its derivatives, many scholars have studied how to reduce the effects of graphene and its derivatives on enzyme conformation and protein structure. As early as 2013, Pattammattel et al. [71] introduced a simple and novel method for improving the structure and activity of enzymes after the combination of enzyme and graphene oxide. And their strategy was to pre-adsorb highly cationized bovine serum albumin to passivate graphene oxide, and bovine serum albumin/graphene oxide served as a splendid platform for enzyme binding [71]. In 2015, Chong et al. [72] selected four highly abundant blood proteins onto graphene, reduced graphene oxide, and SWCNTs. The result showed that cytotoxicity was dramatically reduced for the protein-coated graphene complexes. The electrostatic interaction of proteins with graphene oxide affects the activity of the protein, which makes the graphene oxide loading enzyme still relatively low in practical applications. Therefore, it is a hot issue to explore the optimal dose tomaintain the balance between bio-application and nano-toxicity of graphene oxide. A year later, Zhang et al. reported an efficient and environment-friendly method of removing graphene oxide and its degradation mechanisms, which provided a method for degrading graphene oxide in the future [73]. There are relatively few studies on the enzymatic degradation of graphene oxide compared to CNTs. Some studies have tested enzymes commonly used for CNT biodegradation, such as horseradish peroxidase, which degrade graphene and its derivatives. It is found that these enzymes have a poor biodegradation effect on graphene.

sections.heading: 5. Comparison of interactions of different carbon nanomaterials with proteins
sections.text:
It can be seen that carbon nanomaterials and proteins are mainly through the π− π stacking, van der Waals forces, electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions. However, from the above discussion, we can clearly understand that different types of carbon nanomaterials have different effects on proteins. After comparing the toxicity of CNTs and hydration of fullerene С60 aqueous solution to both oxidoreductase and luciferase, it was found that CNTs have a greater impact on certain enzymes than hydration of fullerene С60 aqueous solution, and the
toxicity of SWCNTs were less than MWCNTs [24]. The toxicity of the same carbon nanomaterial modified by different functional groups to catalase are also different in the same case [74].Moreover, some authors have indicated that the biotoxicity of fullerenes were relatively tiny compared to other carbon nanomaterials, and its toxicity may be derived from impurities introduced during the preparation process [75]. Interestingly, the ability of carbon nanomaterials to adsorb proteins is related to the curvature of their surface. The flat graphene sheet has a stronger adsorption capacity for bovine serum proteins than carbon nanotubes [76]. Many carbon nanomaterials can induce conformational changes in proteins, but different types of nanomaterials produce different degrees of conformational changes. Unmodified carbon nanotubes can inhibit trypsin activity, but alcoholized graphene oxide can significantly increase trypsin activity [77]. From the paperswe have discussed, it can be known that carbon nanomaterials are potentially toxic to proteins. There is no doubt that enzymatic degradation of carbon nanomaterials should be more focused in the future. Currently, there are relatively few studies on enzymatic degradation of graphene and fullerene compared to CTNs. Some researchers used enzymes that could effectively degrade CNTs to degrade fullerenes and graphene and found that enzymatic degradation of CNTs is simpler than enzymatic degradation of graphene and fullerenes [78], which may be related to their unique structure and properties. The interaction of proteins and carbon nanomaterialsmay beginwith the contact between the amino acid which are the basic building blocks of proteins and the functional groups of the carbon nanomaterial [79]. Although there are many studies on the interaction between proteins and nanomaterials, the interaction mechanism and the biotoxicity of nanomaterials are still controversial (What causes carbon nanomaterials to have different effects on proteins? Is there a better enzymatic degradation of carbon nanomaterials? How can modified carbon nanomaterials reduce the toxic effects on proteins?), which requires further research.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion and outlook
sections.text:
In this review, we have provided a comprehensive insight into how proteins response to three common carbonnanomaterials including fullerenes, CNTs and graphene together with their derivatives. So far, fullerenes have been involved in the field research of many disciplines, and have shown great application potential and research value, while the research of the biological effects of fullerenes and their derivatives have just begun. In the future study, we should deeply and systematically study the relationship between fullerenes and biomolecules, such as enzymes and proteins, and explore the regulations of their interactions microscopically to obtain new materials with outstanding performance. Biomolecules can improve the solubility of CNTs. Studying their interaction mechanism can provide a theoretical basis for the application of CNTs in clinical medicine such as bio-imaging and disease detection.Many studies have reported that graphene and its derivatives enter the organism to cause biological toxic effects, so understanding the mechanism of their interaction can provide research directions for eliminating graphene and its derivatives in the environment. In the interaction between carbon nanomaterials and proteins, most of the literature
only pays attention to the influence of carbon nanomaterials on proteins, and lacks research on the changes of carbon nanomaterials. Both changes in nanomaterials and proteins should be investigated seriously because they are interactive. Every coin has two sides, so does the interaction of carbon nanomaterials and protein. Therefore, we also need to study and evaluate the biotoxicity of carbon nanomaterials and enzyme/protein complexes to ensure the availability of new materials. In summary, themechanism of interaction between carbon nanomaterials and biomolecules needs further research, which is crucial for the toxicity assessment of nanomaterials and the safe application of nanomaterials.

referenceMentions.context: Carbon nanomaterials have at least one dimension less than 100 nm [1].
Three different dimensions, zero-dimensional (fullerene), one-dimensional (carbon nanotubes, CNTs) and twodimensional (graphene), are the fundamental forms of carbon nanomaterials [2].
Fullerene, as a new type of carbon nanomaterial, was discovered in 1985 [3] with 20 hexagons and 12 pentagons, consisted of 32 faces [4].
superconductivity, magnetism, optics, catalytic and biocompatibility due to their high degree of symmetry [5].
Almost insoluble in water and sparingly soluble in polar solvent may be one of the disadvantages of fullerenes [6].
CNTs, also called buckytubes, are seamless, hollow nanotubes that are composed by single or multi-layer graphite sheets curled at a certain angle around the center [7].
CNTs can be classified into single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) [2].
CNTs can be synthesized by arc discharge method, chemical vapor deposition, laser method, template method, etc [8,9].
CNTs can be synthesized by arc discharge method, chemical vapor deposition, laser method, template method, etc [8,9].
CNTs are widely used in biological fields such as drug carriers, bio-imaging, and biosensors [10,11].
CNTs are widely used in biological fields such as drug carriers, bio-imaging, and biosensors [10,11].
Graphene is a single layer film composed of sp2-hybridized carbon atoms with extremely high crystal and electron quality [12].
In addition, graphene has a theoretical surface area of up to 2630 m(2)/g that is higher than many materials [13].
Moreover, carbon nanomaterials can enter the organism, andwill not change or degrade during the transfer process [14].
Proteins are the most abundant organic compounds in cells which are the basic unit of structure and function of organisms [15].

Fullerenes and their derivatives have different effects on the structure or activity of the proteins (Table 1), depending on the type of proteins (enzymes), the structure of the carbon nanomaterials, and the chemical groups attached to the nanomaterials [16].
[18] have conducted amore in-depth study on the interaction between fullerene derivatives and HIV-1 protease.
synthesized two different water-soluble fullerene derivatives [19].

After that, Barzegar [20] constructed new carbon nanostructures of fullerenewith one and two polar acetoxyhydroxyl groups (C60-A and C60-B, respectively) and analyzed the interactions and the binding affinity of HIV-1 protease active site and fullerene.
In addition to inhibiting HIV-1 protease, fullerenes and their derivatives could act as inhibitors of the zinc enzymes carbonic anhydrases [21].

[22] found that fullerene derivatives housing – OH, –NH2, and amino acid modified groups inhibited key antioxidant enzymes because fullerene derivatives binds to the active site residues of the amino acids in these enzymes via van der Waals interactions.
In 2016, protein tyrosine phosphatases with comparable shape and size were found to be more easily combined with fullerene inhibitors [23].
[24] demonstrated that fullerene inhibited oxidoreductase and luciferase, while the immobilized enzyme system oxidoreductase and luciferase were more sensitive to fullerene.
[25] also confirmed that the amino-modified fullerene derivative had a significant inhibitory effect on protein tyrosine phosphatase and could be used as an effective inhibitor.
derivatives HIV-1 protease HIV-1 protease were inhibited by fullerene with phenethylamino- succinate [17]

Fullerene-based HIV protease inhibitor influenced the enzyme activity through reversible and competitive ways [18,19] The higher affinity of fullerene with polar acetoxyhydroxyl groups compared to C60 when they interacted with HIV-1 protease.

Fullerene-based HIV protease inhibitor influenced the enzyme activity through reversible and competitive ways [18,19] The higher affinity of fullerene with polar acetoxyhydroxyl groups compared to C60 when they interacted with HIV-1 protease.
Zinc enzymes Fullerenes and their derivatives could act as inhibitors of the zinc enzymes carbonic anhydrases [21]
enzymes Fullerene binds to the active site residues of these enzymes via van der Waals interactions [22]
The amino-modified fullerene derivative had a significant inhibitory effect on protein tyrosine phosphatase [25]
Lysozyme Lysozyme was used as a model protein to study the reaction mechanism of protein and fullerene [26]
Fullerene binding polar groups can reduce the binding between lysozyme and fullerene derivatives [29]
peroxidase Fullerene with the highly curved surface can enhance the stability of the enzyme strongly [30] 103 X.
[26] synthesized and isolated lysozyme-fullerene complex for the first time in 2005.
Through molecular docking technology it was found that fullerene binding to polar groups could reduce the binding between proteins and fullerene derivatives [29].
[30] discovered that fullerene with the highly curved surface could enhance the stability of the enzyme (soybean peroxidase) strongly in denaturing environments to greater extent than flat supports.
Fullerenes also can protect proteins from damage caused by reactive oxygen species besides promote proteins stability [31].
[27], and subsequently were found to have antioxidant function [28].
[27], and subsequently were found to have antioxidant function [28].
But it isworth noting that the unmodified fullerene is less biotoxic to proteins than its derivatives under certain conditions [32].
[33] showed that most of the proteins in the aqueous solution spontaneously adsorbed
Some studies have observed the strong adsorption of fibrinogen on the surface of SWCNTs by scanning electron microscopy and near edge X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy [34].
[35] also concluded that charge transfer could strongly influence the interaction between proteins and carbon nanomaterials and enhanced conformational entropy by inducing protein unfolding.

In addition to the influence of charge transfer, the interaction of carbon nanomaterials and proteins are also related to van der Waals force and Coulomb force, which was confirmed in the experiments of β-amyloid peptides fibrillation and CNTs interaction [36].
[37] found that the aromatic content of surface-active peptides in proteins also plays an significant role in the adsorption of SWCNTs through molecular dynamics simulations.
Many studies have confirmed the organisms toxicity of carbon nanomaterials [38], and the potential toxicity would be affected by CNTs with different degrees of densities and agglomeration.
[39] used molecular dynamic simulation to study the inhibition of α-chymotrypsin (α-ChT) by carboxyl-functionalized SWCNTs with different densities.
[40] concluded that the binding mechanism of carbon nanomaterials and plasma proteins might intensely rely on the oxygen density of the nanomaterials, especially the number of C\\O and C_O bonds.
fluence on the orientation of α-ChT and the conformation of the active site [39]
e serum albumin can alleviate the inhibition of P450 enzyme activity [41]
e induced significant conformational transformation by SWCNTs [45]
boxylated SWCNTs because at the enzyme binding site, Mn bound to surface [54]
, and had an active influence on the thermal stability of papain [49]
important role in influencing adsorption protein stability [51]
in accelerating nanotubes degradation compared to commonly oxidized CNTs [53]
[41] explain that in the presence of SWCNTs with experiments, and the metabolism of drugs in the organism can be disturbed.
However, polyethylene glycol covalently functionalized SWCNTs and SWCNT pre-coated bovine serum albumin can alleviate the inhibition of P450 enzyme activity [41].
[42] added MWCNTs, and carboxylic functionalized MWCNTs to 10 mg/L atrazine respectively, and compared the effects of CNTs on bacterial growth.

found that lactate dehydrogenase spontaneously adsorbs CNTs when CNTs interact with lactate dehydrogenase, and the artifacts occurred in specific conditions, which may be due to the inherent absorption of CNTs [43].
The microbial enzyme-catalyzed courses of organic contaminants would be significantly affected by SWCNT release [44].

[45] found that in the presence of SWCNTs, maleylpyruvate isomerase and lignin peroxidase were induced with significant conformational transformation, and the protein tightnesswas changed and the protein cavity was adjusted.
And the results of this study show that nanomaterials alter the amount and behavior of water molecules adjacent to manganese peroxidase and its substrates [46].
[47] found that SWCNTs could change the microenvironment and conformation of human serum albumin.

And the result showed that the thermal stability and activity of porcine trypsin were reduced in the presence of carboxylic functionalized MWCNTs, while carboxylic functionalized MWCNTs had tiny effect on the conformational change of the porcine trypsin [48].
[49] studied the activity and stability of papain adsorbed by MWCNTs.
[50] found that the dispersed CNTs were the least toxic, and the nanotoxicity of agglomeration was much greater than that of asbestos fibers.
[51] prepared functionalized MWCNTs with diverse diameters and used some equipment to observe the conformation of protein, backbone changes, and the secondary structural stability.
[52] investigated the difference between the binding of individual SWCNTs and polymerized SWCNTs to dopamine-related proteins through all-atom molecular dynamic simulation.
[54] compared the enzymatic transformation of SWCNTs and carboxylated SWCNTs by using three enzymes to explore the enzyme degradation mechanism of SWCNTs.
[55] provided a molecular basis for the degradation of CNTs by comparing the interaction of manganese peroxidase and lignin peroxidase with CNTs.

In addition, they also found that the original CNTs are difficult to be degraded by enzymes, such as horseradish peroxidase and lactoperoxidase, and CNT biodegradation usually requires functionalization [56].
[57] first reported a naturally occurring graphene and demonstrated its unique physicochemical properties, more and more people have studied this material.
Graphene is hydrophobic, while graphene oxide is easily soluble in water and many solvents [58].
The preparation of graphene oxide mainly includes Brodie method [59], Staudenmaier method [60] and electrochemical oxidation method.
The preparation of graphene oxide mainly includes Brodie method [59], Staudenmaier method [60] and electrochemical oxidation method.
The toxicity of graphene depends on the chemical structure, surface properties, size, dosage, and exposure time of graphene [61,62].
The toxicity of graphene depends on the chemical structure, surface properties, size, dosage, and exposure time of graphene [61,62].

[63] used all-atommolecular dynamics simulations to analyze potential toxicity of graphene via the hydrophobic protein-protein interactions and concluded that a graphene nanosheet can interrupt the hydrophobic protein-protein interaction and even result in the mortality of a cell.
[64] demonstrated that graphene oxide exhibited the highest inhibition dose response for α-ChT inhibition.
[65], and they found that the toxicity of graphene oxide to microorganisms was dose-dependent.

[66] studied the reaction of three carbon nanomaterials (carbon black,multiwalled carbon nanotubes, graphene oxide) with serum albumin, and measured the binding strength of serum albumin to these three nanomaterials.

[67] found that both graphene and graphene oxide obviously reduced enzyme stability by changing enzyme conformation through the experiment of the interaction between horseradish peroxidase and three graphene-based nanomaterials.
[68] used molecular dynamic simulations to
Graphene Blood proteins Graphene could interrupt the hydrophobic protein-protein interaction [63]
peroxidase Both graphene obviously reduced enzyme stability by changing enzyme conformation [67]
oxide α-ChT Graphene oxide exhibited high inhibition response for α-ChT [64]
Serum albumin Graphene oxide had a high adsorption capacity for serum albumin, but its binding specificity was low [66]
Graphene oxide could improve the structure and activity of enzymes by preadsorbing highly cationized bovine serum albumin [71]
Glucose oxidase Graphene oxide has no competitive inhibition on glucose oxidase, but has competitive inhibition on L-lactate dehydrogenase [70] 105 X.

[69] studied the affinity, conformational structure, thermal stability and non-enzymatic glycosylation of graphene oxide-hemoglobin binding by fluorescence spectroscopy and circular dichroism spectroscopy.
[70] investigated the interaction of graphene oxide with two enzymes: glucose oxidase and L-lactate dehydrogenase.
[71] introduced a simple and novel method for improving the structure and activity of enzymes after the combination of enzyme and graphene oxide.
And their strategy was to pre-adsorb highly cationized bovine serum albumin to passivate graphene oxide, and bovine serum albumin/graphene oxide served as a splendid platform for enzyme binding [71].
[72] selected four highly abundant blood proteins onto graphene, reduced graphene oxide, and SWCNTs.
reported an efficient and environment-friendly method of removing graphene oxide and its degradation mechanisms, which provided a method for degrading graphene oxide in the future [73].

After comparing the toxicity of CNTs and hydration of fullerene С60 aqueous solution to both oxidoreductase and luciferase, it was found that CNTs have a greater impact on certain enzymes than hydration of fullerene С60 aqueous solution, and the toxicity of SWCNTs were less than MWCNTs [24].
The toxicity of the same carbon nanomaterial modified by different functional groups to catalase are also different in the same case [74].

Moreover, some authors have indicated that the biotoxicity of fullerenes were relatively tiny compared to other carbon nanomaterials, and its toxicity may be derived from impurities introduced during the preparation process [75].
The flat graphene sheet has a stronger adsorption capacity for bovine serum proteins than carbon nanotubes [76].
Unmodified carbon nanotubes can inhibit trypsin activity, but alcoholized graphene oxide can significantly increase trypsin activity [77].

Some researchers used enzymes that could effectively degrade CNTs to degrade fullerenes and graphene and found that enzymatic degradation of CNTs is simpler than enzymatic degradation of graphene and fullerenes [78], which may be related to their unique structure and properties.

The interaction of proteins and carbon nanomaterialsmay beginwith the contact between the amino acid which are the basic building blocks of proteins and the functional groups of the carbon nanomaterial [79].

metadata.abstractText: Article history: 30 May 2019 Available online 05 June 2019 Carbon nanomaterials are widely produced and applied in biological and environmental fields because of their outstanding physical and chemical properties, which pose a threat to the safety of living organisms and the ecological environment. Therefore, understanding how carbon nanomaterials and their derivatives work on organisms is becoming important. In recent years, more and more researchers have explored the damage of carbon nanomaterials to organisms at the molecular level. This review pays special emphasis on how proteins response to themain carbonnanomaterials (fullerene, carbon nanotubes, graphene and their derivatives). In addition, how to use the interaction between carbon nanomaterials and proteins to do some beneficial things for human and the development of safe nanomaterials is simply discussed. Finally, some suggestions have been made to lay a theoretical foundation for future research. © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
